title: What will be the value of Total Assets of the Federal Reserve as of Wednesday 30 December 2020?
possible_answers: More than $9 trillion but less than $10 trillion
preds: It is only at 7.2 trillion as of 9 December, so I think it will stay low.
Balance was $7.18 trillion on December 2. No indication purchases will spike enough to push above $8 trillion by December 30.
The outcome of the elections and the senate, means that the package is not going to be available until Jan 2021.
The year's end draws closer, and the fed hasn't yet gotten close enough to the 8tn number to make me think it'll happen.
markt to market, even with potential for increased QE, not enough time given current 7.2tn size to get above 8 before year-end
not much fed action .. mostly going to be less during lame duck session ...
>$8 trillion if... and only if, the Fed purchases more assets. Other than that, a +14% hike on treasuries is not happening.
QE has slowed a bit and there isn’t much time to get it started back up again.

They are buying around $120 Billion a month, including junk bonds, and it seems that risk value is directly correlated, if they keep this pace they will end at $7.3 Trillion  and change. As of the last 10 years the Fed is the prop of the risk economy!

Not sure about any of this. US cases are highest, markets are falling so maybe there'll be another spike in Fed assets if Trump wins? Doesn't seem like there'll be much movement after elections if Biden wins

The current total assets of the Fed Balance sheet is 7.15 trillion. Regardless of who wins the elections, fiscal stimulus is very likely to come before or after the election. The current proposed fiscal stimulus is 1.8 - 2.2 trillion. This is likely to be funded via government bond issuance. some of this will be absorbed via primary dealer banks, the majority will be absorbed onto the fed balance sheet. The counter argument is the that there is stalemate in the run up to the elections, and stimulus does not come, however this is against both the interest of the republicans and the white house as a booming stock market is going to be more favourable for the incumbent. The democrats will want to delay, but as soon as the numbers 1.8 - 2.2 converge closer the stimulus package should be signed. Assuming the Fed takes on 50% of 2 trillion in bonds, this makes the balance sheet 8.1 trillion.

Their current balance sheet is 7 trillion. They are buying at the pace of 120 billion a month, which is 360 billion over the next three months. In order to hit 8 trillion, they would need to triple their pace of buying, which would only happen if you either had (a) a massive amount of treasury issuance hit the market which needed to be absorbed or (b) significant asset market weakness, rising credit spreads and borrowing rates. The odds of (a) have rapidly diminished, and while you certainly could see some asset weakness, I doubt it gets to the level where this type of Fed buying is needed (in particular because it will cause enough pain to warrant fiscal action).

I had it maxed for the lower bucket for a while to help make up for my previous position the other direction. Now my forecast is an actual forecast again.  Factoring in Trump's statement on the Limbaugh show that he wants more than the Democrat position of $2.4 tril in stimulus. There is no longer a gap in the Democrat/Republican position, so a stimulus deal is likely. also a possibility of some disaster relief spending for the hurricane, which is always off the books debt spending just like the stimulus spending would be. All of this spending would have to be covered by the treasury issuing debt. And this last year the Fed has bought up >100% of newly issued debt.

The federal peaked it asset buy in June and assets have remained at a plateau near $7 trillion. 
https://wolfstreet.com/2020/09/10/dont-fight-the-fed-feds-assets-in-week-13-since-peak-qe/
https://www.federalreserve.gov/releases/h41/current/ Since the fed seeks an "accommadative" policy:
"Fed officials are also mulling when and how to update their asset purchase program — which involves buying large quantities of Treasury securities and government-backed bonds — and said Wednesday that they would maintain purchases “at least” at their current pace to “sustain smooth market functioning and help foster accommodative financial conditions.”
https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/09/16/business/stock-market-today-coronavirus
Currently hovering at 7bn.  Looks like this value is being maintained.  Could increase to 8bn, but not likely to make bin 3.
Even if they monetize half of a 1.5 trillion plan they wont get there

Current assets are about 7 trillion. If they keep on their 120 bln per month pace, they would be well less than the 8 trillion dollar cap. However, there is a probability of them increasing their purchases if there is economic weakness or if newly passed stimulus puts an upward pressure on interest rates. Given the election and their desire to preserve some modicum of institutional independence, they will likely not buy unless they have to. And it's hard to imagine buying more than the stimulus package which will be less than 2 trillion. In addition, they might be able to get away with talk of unlimited purchases without actually doing them.

Anything above 1/2 of the annual GDP puts the Fed on a Japanese spiral of continuum risk purchases, consequently risk asset inflation, as of now they have already started to affect the ETF market specially on the junk side, so market price discovery is off the window.
Fed is monetizing but without more Congressional spending there's no reason to add.

Adjusting down. Although the pace has picked up a little and we get long-term reassurances, there is very little indication that asset purchases will pick up significantly until the next Fed meeting - unless there is a severe stock market crash. But that is far less likely than the current 57% crowd forecast for > 8trn.

The fiscal year starts Oct 1. I think this will require a new round of debt issuance by the US Treasury which the FED will have to cover. Also I expect another stimulus/state relief/disaster aid package by end of year. Aid packages are always off budget and will have to be covered by the Fed. Retail sales have already dropped off with the unemployment aid ending.

This being an election year, I would have thought that the president would be twisting Republican senators' arms to pass an aid bill.  I have no idea why he hasn't done so, since it's clearly in his interests.  Maybe there is a sense that the economy doesn't need it.  Maybe he just doesn't want a fight within his party before the election.  Ya, I think that's it.
balance sheet growth appears to have stalled, chance Fed increases purchases as Treasury issuance ramps into fall but given ample liquidity and market stability odds are being lowered

I think they're likely to do nothing big or be forced to do nothing large package in the 2-3 Trillion range. They've shown they're willing to do what it takes to save the stock market and it's doing fine right now. the likelihood of it crashing again is decent in my mind

(Use toggle feature at the bottom of chart to zoom in for 2020)
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/WALCL
Given current Fed balance sheet trends, I think this question should do well with a "barbell response" - inspired by the barbell portfolio popularized by Nassim Taleb: betting the wings.
The most likely scenario going forward is underwhelming demand for Fed credit lines as banks have been flooded with deposits. (https://app.ft.com/content/73177be1-71cf-4e31-9590-a296a2ba16c7) 
Alternatively, we will see a sharp break in volatility suppression and a second leg down similar to what happened from Feb 20th to Mar 20th. In that case, more than 1.5tn should be necessary to avoid total meltdown, as the market structure problems have become worse and not better compared to half a year ago (i.e. excessive leverage as a response to insufficient yields, increase in Junk and Spacs uptake etc.).
This question merits a lot more discussion, but I will leave it at this and add more later as the period is fairly long term given the fickle nature of financial markets.

There is no doubt that the federal government is running extremely high deficits.  More help for jobless people will be needed or there will be tens of millions of newly homeless people in the country.  If millions of mortgages go unpaid the banks will fail.  Likewise unpaid rent leads to financial stress for property owners.  The government is not going to let 30-50 million of people go bankrupt, so deficit spending will be with us for quite a while. If the treasury spends money that it doesn't have it can just create money with a few strokes of a keyboard.  That increases the total assets on the Fed's balance sheet.  The other way to finance deficit spending is to borrow the money by selling bonds. Although interest rates are incredibly low, pension funds, insurance companies, and other investors are buying bonds like crazy.  [This cannot end well, IMHO. But I don't know how it will end, other than with years of financial repression.  Forget about earning interest on your savings for a decade or more.]   So a basic question, to which I do not know the answer, is whether the treasury will finance deficit spending through more money creation, or by selling bonds that yield essentially nothing to willing investors. If they sell too many bonds it could, at some point, spook the market and cause bond rates to rise.  They don't want that.  But they can always buy any bonds that the market does not want, and hold them on the Fed's balance sheet. The crowd is betting on lower numbers.  I'm going to bet that at some point before the end of the year, possibly during the much anticipated second wave of the virus, the bond market will start to choke on low-yielding  bonds.  And the Fed will have to buy a couple of trillion dollars worth. I'm not a finance guy, so if I'm in the weeds on how this works please set me straight.

Wells Fargo research (8/3/20): "The balance sheet of the Federal Reserve has expanded to nearly $7.0 trillion from about $4.2 trillion in late February. Under our base-case scenario, we project that it will grow to roughly $7.6 trillion by the end of the year, although we acknowledge that the balance sheet could climb higher if the FOMC needs to provide even more monetary accommodation to the economy."

There is a high probability of a Coronavirus relief bill becoming law in the next couple of weeks.  Splitting the difference between the Republican's $1 trillion proposal and the Democrats $3 trillion proposal, and adding it to the approximately $7 trillion in existing assets makes around $9 trillion.
6,949,032 Millions today. Tweeking a few. Fed is buying assets so likely to go up. How much?

Over 100% of government spending has been financed by the Federal reserve this year. There is no appetite to buy us treasuries. Other countries have their own problems. By the end of the year Congress will pass all sorts of stimulus, bailout, and possibly infrastructure bills. The only way to pay for this will be by printing money.

~55% of US gov spending this year has been paid for buy the Fed. Congress is ready to pass a $550 bil bill to bail out commercial mortgages. It's only July. We will see many more such bills, and they will all need to be funded by the Fed.  The recent down tick in the balance sheet has to do with banks no longer surrendering as many assets for overnight lending. It doesn't have to do with the long run balance sheet. Powell has made it clear the Fed will NOT be selling off its balance sheet. Ever. The plan is to let the economy grow until the balance sheet no longer matters. Powell does not even want to signal the possibility the Fed might sell.

Although Q2 bank balance sheets were flush with deposits, that was largely driven by SBA and IRS stimulus payments in addition to increase in federal unemployment benefits. Many banks may face liquidity issues as those short term bursts in deposits run off and deferred loans become due.  Between March and the end of June assets increased sharply, there has been a slight decrease in early Q2 - this is not likely to last.
updating given slowing pace of growth, but expecting re-acceleration at slower pace given recent fed governor comments
No real insight here, but a wild guess with the assumption that most of Fed's work is done for now
6.97 today. Next stimulus bill will add some but the money is not all for buying buying assets.
Fed will do whatever it takes ... and that includes saving more companies as the economy slumps again

19 July reserves just under 7tn.  Values plateaued in the last month but coronavirus only just taking off in large parts of the world.  Expecting another increase in the next month or two, but feel there will be some kind of ceiling somewhere between 9 and 11tn.
Moving the probability distribution a bit to the left as retail investors are taking care of what the Fed expected to be doing, i.e. mopping up junk assets.

Revising my prediction down based on how the FED has been slowing down their asset purchases. However, I'm still pessimistic about the economy and I know the FED will step in to purchase assets as soon as the market takes another downturn, so I still believe more purchases will happen this year. Especially if Congress passes another stimulus bill which requires funding. The current stimulus runs out at the end of August I think. At the current rate of purchases the balance sheet will not break 8 trillion by the end of the year, but I am confident that asset purchases will pick up at some point, possibly on a massive scale.

Decreasing likelihood further rounds of QE will be necessary:   liquidity seems to have normalized, high frequency economic indicators largely improving since May.   The balance sheet has been declining since early June, shrinking about $200b to about $7t.    The wild cards are impact of COVID wave two and how much Treasury issuance the Fed will need to take down.
I mixed up QE with assets. Although they are very strongly linked, there are some significant differences.
The likelihood of another bailout looms.
Positive economic data suggests a slow down of QE will take place.

The stock market has been climbing while we have had record unemployment. The stock market is unconnected to fundamentals now. The stock market directly correlates with the Fed balance sheet. All the governors on the Fed board are multi millionaires heavily invested in the stock market. The Fed has committed to buying $750 billion in junk corporate bonds. 55% of Federal spending this year has been Funded by the Fed monetizing debt. Any additional spending by Congress will have to be paid for by the Fed. Many spending bills are bring contemplated including a massive infrastructure bill and another stimulus bill. Also a likely reparations bill and student loan forgiveness bill, but those won't be this year. As the public realizes that there won't be much of an economic recovery we will see a new round of layoffs and business closures which will prompt more stimulus, both monetary and fiscal. And any fiscal stimulus will be paid for by the Fed. Jerome Powell has made it clear the Fed is "not even thinking about thinking about raising interest rates" and that they will continue to do whatever is required regardless of inflation. Powell also said directly they have no plans to ever sell off the balance sheet. Ever. They hope the economy will grow large enough to make the balance sheet small. They plan to print their way to prosperity. $3 Trillion has been added in the last three months. Increases to the balance sheet have slowed down the last few weeks, but it is very realistic we could see another $3 trillion in each of the next quarters, bringing us to $13 trillion. Also of note, Powell has strongly stated that the Fed board is not in favor of negative interest rates. With interest rates at zero this means the only tool they have remaining is expanding the balance sheet.
The Fed will do its thing and make sure that the market stays propped up. I think that we will see more direct lending from them.

The latest Fed balance sheet figures actually show a reduction in the balance sheet size b/w 9th and 16th July (from 7.169 T to 7.095 T). 
- https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/bst_recenttrends.htm Though this does not affect how big the balance sheet will be in the medium term (by end of Dec 2020), I am moving more weight into the lower buckets. Will watch and revise as needed.

Surprisingly the Feds holding went down on 6/17/20, this made me reconsider and lower my initial prediction. While their asset holdings may have to go up a bit, the Fed is currently holding an insane amount of assets and should be looking to rid themselves of some.
Currently 7.1T.  Probable some stimulus in 2nd half.

The Fed will continue asset purchases throughout the year but at a steadily declining rate until a more consistent fiscal stimulus emerges that will come in early fall as Democrats and Trump line up for the election.
Wave 2 of coronavirus will rock the economy.
Over 7 now. Have to watch rate of increase.

The FED has monetized 105% of debt issued by the Treasury this year. Congress is going to keep spending money and passing stimulus which will need to be funded. Plus the FED will be buying mortgages and even stocks. They are hesitant to go negative on interest rates. Creating money is their only trick and Powell has made it clear there is no limit.

currently 7.169 trillion, they just announced about 120bln a month, we have 6.5 months left so 7.949. they are leaning toward taper if things get better and more QE if things get worse. at the max they would probably double the purchases if we have another downturn. Rates are very low, seems more likely they intervene in the mortgage market, or if they announce explicit yield curve control.

Currently near 8 Trillion. The stock market remains unstable. Interest rates are virtually zero. Investing in the economy is one of the few tools it has to control the economy. The questions that will factor into decisions are still without answers. Will our economy recover? When will things become stable again? How will CoVid19 impact businesses globally? Who will be elected president?

This increasing balance is in direct response to economic conditions caused by COVID. As the economy opens up and companies adapt to new ways of doing business, the need to buy these securities will decrease. While there are calls for the fed to address racial inequality, I believe most efforts will be in culture and legislation and not with the fed, which will likely be the last to make major changes in philosophy. The curve is still increasing, but has slowed considerably. Also, stimulus monies have largely been sent out and the odds of a major new stimulus are low unless there is another insurgence of COVID or some other economic disaster.
This will be required to deal with pandemic
The lower end is more likely given the amount of unemployment and other support needed, but depending on how things pan out it could be across quite a range this far out from December.

I believe the coronavirus situation is at the beginning stages of a second resurgence. I also believe many states will wait as long as possible to reimplement lockdowns due to the mass opposition from citizens and businesses. Therefore, I believe the situation will be worse than during the first wave even though I believe the rate of spread will be less due to some social distancing and preventative measures currently in place. The case counts will be higher, along with hospitalizations and deaths. And, everyone will realize that the restrictions were lifted too early which implies the next round of lockdowns will be in place longer. Now, the existing government aid is ending soon, and there is talk of additional support. This existing government aid lasted for ~3-4 months. Any additional support would likely need to be enough to cover a minimum of the same time period, but likely longer due to the above. It also may need to be substantially more because many individuals and businesses can survive a short lockdown without income or revenue on existing savings and minimal stimulus. But an additional lockdown just after the first one when it’s expected to last longer, will be a bigger strain and therefore require more government help. Now, assuming the existing assets on the balance sheet aren’t written down significantly because they’re “essentially” backed by the FED, this implies substantially more will be required from the government. I believe the situation described above highlights that the existing $3 trillion increase would be needed again (at a minimum) if the situation was the same as the first. But considering I believe it will be substantially worse and longer in duration, I believe the stimulus will need to be substantially higher. So, I believe the number will be above $11 trillion.
No real knowledge, just eyeballing the trends.
Based on recent historical data there will be a steady increase in the feds total assets.
Historic growth shows that it will keep expanding

The fed is under immense political pressure, which is a ridiculous statement as I type it out but it is true. They will continue to prop up a bubbling market as much as possible, delving into increased bond buying and I wouldn’t discount equity activity before all is said and done.
Things are clearly going to get economically worse and Trump will do everything he can to prop up his chances of winning re-election.

I do not believe that they can prop up the economy without a united front. I believe separating the politics from the economy is only possible when the politics are being down played. Between elections, COVID-19,unemployment, poor leadership world economy will be under pressure to let u.s.  fend for itself since we are not even confronting our own economic woes.
Democrats to win all houses of Congress plus the WH and will super charge spending programs. MMT will be put into effect.

The treasury and the Fed are working hand in hand. Treasury secretary says we cannot shut down the economy again, and they will inject $1 trillion into economy in June alone. That's not fiscal, that is monetary. And congress is passing a $1 trillion bill which will need to be paid for with borrowed money.
https://www.zerohedge.com/markets/mnuchin-scrambles-halt-stock-rout-says-will-pump-another-1-trillion-economy-month

Yesterday the Fed announced that they would continue QE at a rate of at least $120bn per month. No indication when and if this will change. Will this number increase/decrease?  It may increase if a second wave of COVID hits, leading to more unemployment and uncertainty. A second wave in fall seems very probable. If the inflation rate starts to gain momentum upwards QE will promptly stop - and everyone should be very very worried haha. It may decrease if re-openings continue to be successful, demand remains to increase, and the unemployment numbers continue to decrease.  I think the average number per month will be above $120bn (around $150/200) and decrease gradually until October. It may then increase due to COVID.  $7,165,217 + between (80,000/200,000 for 18 weeks) + between (100,000/350,000 for 9 weeks) = between $9,505,217 and $13,915,217. A lot of uncertainty, this question is very tricky. Criticism is very welcome!

Bad times are a coming. And the only trick they have is creating money. They will buy more than just bonds and mortgages, they will buy stocks and corporate bonds. And the US still has trillions of debt to finance. And congress will undoubtedly pass another trillion dollars stimulus which will need to be borrowed for. Right now it's the EUs turn to buy things up, but it will be the FEDs turn again soon.

I am making a baseline estimate while taking the cowards way out. I estimate that while the balance sheet will expand, it will not expand to the extreme. Thereby giving the 9 trillion to 10 trillion bucket the maximum probability.  NB: Initially I had around 50% for the 9-10 bucket. But flattened the curve when it hit home that the buckets are just 1 trillion wide. And whats a trillion nowadays!

Backing off of high end a touch.  Also found the concept in the below article supportive of this, and an interesting concept to watch here...  https://www.marketwatch.com/story/get-ready-for-the-fed-to-start-targeting-bond-yields-outright-in-september-says-baml-analyst-2020-06-04
Adding more weight to Fed treasury purchase branch

Assuming the financial crisis is contained, at the current trajectory, the balance would level off under $8t. Some chance of need for one-off QE bumps puts possibility of going over into the low $9t range.  The bigger wild card is how much treasury issuance the Fed will end up buying.  I'm assuming 50% chance of $3t, which puts the balance at about $11t.  Rather than carry my probability for >8t, I split the difference between 10-11 and >11 because my $3t purchase is more likely to be exceeded if this branch is followed.

The directional bias is bigger, as long as C19 is impacting the real economy enough to put marginally financed businesses at risk of default.  If recent protests result in an upsurge in cases, then more growth is likely.  If not, then only creeping growth to keep markets liquid plus however much they buy from Treasury, maybe $3tr.  The Last round of QT lead to liquidity problems in repo market and contributed to late 2018 stock market drawdown.  Unlikely to shrink balance sheet before economic flywheel is spinning faster, so little chance of less than $8b.

Considering the Fed is investing in bonds, the upside is assured but muted compared to that of what equities will see. I think we should pump the brakes a bit here... especially in light of a Democratic win reactionary sell off and ongoing economic recovery reality. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-05-29/fed-reveals-which-etfs-it-purchased-in-emergency-lending-program

We're already at $7.1 trillion dollars, according to the Federal Reserve website that will determine the outcome.  It's hard to believe that it won't increase significantly from here.  The Democratically controlled House of Representatives wants $3T more money to help states.  Currently the Republican Senate doesn't want to spend more, but it's early days for this challenge. When the economy doesn't bounce back sufficiently to restore fiscal stability to hard-hit states the choice will be between bankruptcy and helicopter money.   States cannot create their own money, but the Federal Reserve can.  Teachers, police, firefighters, and hospital workers would be impacted if cities and states declare bankruptcy.  Our choice will be between a bailout or a breakdown of civil society.  I believe we will simply print the money.  The only real question is how much.

First forecast based on other forecaster's comments and sources [1,2,3]. Reluctant to go to any extremes at the moment. However, it is not impossible we'll see the volume exceed $10 trillion. A lot depends whether there will be - and on the type of - recovery in the next months. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1041041
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1038286
[3] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/1038070

There is a lot of pressure for another round of income support for unemployed Americans, but  continuing disputes with corporates over liability protections related to virus outbreaks will limit the total sum that is allocated.

27th May, current sheet is 7tr, the current buying rate is 10bn a day, 7 months, 20 biz days = c.1.4tr
that gets to 8-9trillion, they will not be reducing balance sheet into this election - political pressure.
today stocks are up but things can get worse with second order in this shutdown, though to have them at above peak is a bit absurd given the economy will be smaller.
Adjusting to respond to the consensus.

CARES Act allocated about $500bn to the Treasury to backstop the Feds lending facilities. The Fed applied roughly 10x leverage to those funds for an address $5.1tn to their balance sheet (precrisis of ~$4tn). I’m not sure how the open market purchases of Treasuries and MBS factored into that amount so my risks are on the upside. That being said, I could see a swifter than expected recovery (possibly driven by pent up consumer demand) convince the Fed to stop closer to $8tn.

During the Great Recession, the value of total assets grew by approximately 240%. If we apply the same growth to the value of total assets before the COVID crisis, we end up at around 10 trillion. Let's assume the Fed's interventions will be slightly more aggressive this time. So we'll give the highest odds to the top three categories. This question will be easier to nail down as we get closer and closer to the closing date.
We are at about 6T now. Republicans want to hold line but 2-3T more might be needed.

Cue "money printer go brrrr" memes... ;-) Assets on Fed balance sheet rose approximately 2.4x from prior status quo in the first round of QE in 2008. Using that to calibrate my forecast, it puts the peak of my curve right around $10MM. Initially based on gut (but subequently supported by a few articles: [1], [2]) I'm adjusting my peak up somewhat, placing the highest probability at between $10-11MM. Seems like all of the political and economic forces are aligned for the QE to floweth freely for some time. This seems supported by the Fed's tone throughout the crisis: "“When it comes to this lending, we’re not going to run out of ammunition, that doesn’t happen” - Jerome Powell [3] [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/27/the-feds-balance-sheet-just-passed-5-trillion-for-the-first-time-ever.html
[2] https://www.marketwatch.com/story/assets-on-fed-balance-sheet-rise-to-record-672-trillion-2020-05-07
[3] https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/26/fed-chair-jerome-powell-on-when-to-restart-the-economy-we-would-tend-to-listen-to-the-experts.html

Forget that the FED is tapering down its treasury purchases. the FED is the buyer of last resort and the US Treasury will be issuing unprecedented amount of debt over the next six months and there is not the appetite in the market to purchase it. Japan, China, and the EU have their own problems and can't possibly absorb that much debt. The FED will be purchasing the lion's share of it. The balance sheet is right now somewhere around seven trillion.  They have purchased almost 3 trillion dollars worth of treasuries in the last 3 months.  The Treasury is borrowing $3.7 trillion in the period from April to September, and most of that is still ahead of us. Congress is currently working on another bailout bill which is currently set to cost another 3 trillion dollars. it is very likely we will see other bailout packages as well. also consider there is a lot of pressure right now for the FED to do negative interest rates but Jerome Powell seems to be resistant to it and has stated that he would support more asset purchases before setting interest rates negative. Jerome Powell just admitted that there is no limit to the amount of money they are willing to create. Looking at past recessions is not relevant to what is happening now. The wheels are coming off the bus. All the Fed has to do is continue buying treasuries at the rate they have been for the last three months to hit $11 trillion, and with the debt issuance coming from the Treasury, the rate of purchases will actually be more than that.

D-FENCE! D-FENCE!
Oh man, I love this question. Can you imagine that balance sheet in whatever recovery we experience..? Kneejerk prediction; will review and reconsider asap.
